title: Introduction to Python
content:
What is Python? A high-level, interpreted programming language focused on readability. Good for beginners and used in web development, scripting, data science, and automation.

Quick facts:
- Interpreted: runs line-by-line
- Dynamic typing: no variable declarations required
- Indentation defines blocks (no braces)

Why use Python?
- Fast to write, large ecosystem, great libraries (requests, pandas, numpy).

title: Variables & Basic Types
content:
Variables hold values. Python detects types automatically.

Common types:
- int: 42
- float: 3.14
- str: "hello"
- bool: True / False
- None: empty value

Use type(x) to inspect a variable's type.
codeExample:
a = 10
b = 3.5
name = "Alice"
flag = True
print(type(a), type(b), type(name), type(flag))
trystarter:
age = 20
name = "YourName"
print(f"{name} is {age} years old.")

title: Operators
content:
Operators perform operations on values.

Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, // (floor), % (mod), ** (power)
Comparison: ==, !=, <, <=, >, >=
Logical: and, or, not
Assignment short-hands: +=, -=, *=, /=

Use parentheses to control evaluation order.
codeExample:
x = 7
y = 3
print(x + y, x - y, x * y, x / y)
print(x // y, x % y, x ** y)
print(x > y, x == y)
print((x > y) and (y > 0))

title: Strings
content:
Strings store text. They are immutable (can't change characters in-place).

Common ops:
- Concatenation: +
- Repetition: *
- Slicing: s[start:end]
- Methods: upper(), lower(), split(), join(), strip(), replace()
- f-strings for formatting: f"{var}"
codeExample:
s = "Hello, Python"
print(s.upper())
print(s[0:5])
name = "Alice"
print(f"Hi, {name}!")

title: Lists (Arrays)
content:
Lists are ordered, mutable collections. They can store mixed types.

Common methods: append(), extend(), insert(), pop(), remove(), sort(), reverse().
Indexing supports negative indices: -1 is last element.
Slicing returns sublists.

title: Tuples, Sets & Dictionaries
content:
Tuples: immutable ordered collections (use for fixed groups).
Sets: unordered collections of unique items (fast membership checks).
Dictionaries: key->value mappings, very common for structured data.

Common dict methods: get(), keys(), values(), items(), pop().

title: Control Flow: If / For / While
content:
If statements direct decisions; for loops iterate over sequences; while repeats until a condition is false.

Remember: indentation defines the block. Use break and continue to control loop flow.

title: Functions
content:
Define reusable code with def. Functions can return values and have default args.

Use *args for variable positional args and **kwargs for keyword args.
Docstrings explain what a function does.
codeExample:
def greet(name='Friend'):
    """Return greeting message"""
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet('Alice'))
print(greet())

title: Comprehensions & Generator Expressions
content:
Comprehensions create sequences concisely: list, set, dict comprehensions.
Generator expressions use parentheses and yield items lazily (memory efficient).

Example: [x*x for x in nums if x%2==0] creates a list of even squares.
codeExample:
nums = list(range(10))
evens = [x for x in nums if x%2==0]
gen = (x*x for x in nums)
print(evens)
print(next(gen))
trystarter:
nums = [1,2,3,4]
print([x*2 for x in nums])

title: File I/O
content:
Read/write files with open(). Prefer the 'with' statement so files close automatically.
Modes: 'r' read, 'w' write (overwrite), 'a' append, 'b' binary.
Always handle file errors in production.
codeExample:
with open('sample.txt','w') as f:
    f.write('Hello\n')

with open('sample.txt','r') as f:
    print(f.read())

title: Error Handling (Exceptions)
content:
Use try/except to catch exceptions and handle errors without crashing.
Structure: try -> except -> else (runs when no exception) -> finally (always runs).
Catch specific exceptions (ValueError, KeyError) rather than a bare except.

title: Classes & OOP
content: Classes bundle data (attributes) and behavior (methods). Use __init__ to initialize objects. Use inheritance to reuse code. Use __str__ and __repr__ for readable object output.

title: Modules, Packages & pip
content:
Modules are .py files you import. Packages are folders with __init__.py. The Python Package Index (PyPI) hosts third-party packages; install with pip.

Best practice: create virtual environments (venv) per project.
codeExample:
import math
print(math.sqrt(25))

# third-party example (install first):
# pip install requests
# import requests

title: Iterators, Generators & Decorators
content: Iterators implement __iter__ and __next__. Generators use yield for lazy sequences. Decorators (@decorator) wrap functions to modify behavior (e.g., logging, timing).

title: Concurrency: threading, multiprocessing & asyncio
content:
Concurrency helps run tasks in parallel.
- threading for I/O-bound tasks (threads share memory)
- multiprocessing for CPU-bound tasks (separate processes)
- asyncio for asynchronous I/O (single-threaded event loop)

Be mindful of race conditions and the GIL (Global Interpreter Lock) for CPU-bound threads.
codeExample:
import asyncio

async def say(x):
    await asyncio.sleep(1)
    print(x)

async def main():
    await asyncio.gather(say('a'), say('b'))

asyncio.run(main())
trystarter:
import threading

def work():
    print('working')

thread = threading.Thread(target=work)
thread.start()
thread.join()

title: Introduction to Java
content:
Java is an object-oriented, statically-typed language that runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). It follows the principle 'Write Once, Run Anywhere'.

Key points:
- Strong static typing
- Automatic memory management (garbage collection)
- Rich standard library and ecosystem
- Commonly used for backend, Android, enterprise systems

title: Variables & Data Types
content:
Java variables must declare a type. Primitive types include int, long, double, float, boolean, char. Objects use reference types (String, arrays, classes).

Use final to create constants. From Java 10+, var allows local type inference.

title: Operators & Expressions
content:
Java supports arithmetic, relational, logical, bitwise, and assignment operators. Note integer division truncates fractional part.

Use parentheses to enforce precedence. Use == for primitives and .equals() for object equality (often for Strings).

title: Strings & String API
content: Strings are objects (immutable). Use methods like length(), substring(), indexOf(), toUpperCase(), split(). For performance use StringBuilder for many concatenations.

title: Control Flow: if / switch / loops
content:
Control structures look similar to other languages: if/else, switch, for, while, do-while. Use enhanced for (for-each) to iterate arrays and collections.

Java 14+ has improved switch expressions.

title: Methods (Functions)
content:
Methods define behavior. Java supports method overloading (same name, different parameters). Methods belong to classes and can be static (class-level) or instance-level.

Signatures: returnType name(params).
trystarter: public static int mul(int a, int b) { return a*b; }

title: Arrays & Collections
content: Arrays are fixed-size. Collections (List, Set, Map) are dynamic and part of java.util. Use ArrayList for dynamic arrays, HashMap for key-value storage, HashSet for unique items.
trystarter:
String[] arr = {"a","b","c"};
for (String s : arr) System.out.println(s);

title: Classes & Objects
content: Classes define blueprints. Use constructors to initialize objects. Fields hold state. Use access modifiers (public, private, protected) for encapsulation.

title: Inheritance & Interfaces
content: Inheritance: class B extends A. Interfaces define contracts that classes implement (implements). Java supports single class inheritance and multiple interfaces. Use @Override to mark overridden methods.
trystarter:
class A{int x;} class B extends A{}
B b = new B();

title: Exceptions & Error Handling
content: Use try/catch/finally to handle exceptions. Java differentiates checked (must be declared/handled) and unchecked (runtime) exceptions. Use throws in method signatures for checked exceptions.
trystarter: try { String s = null; s.length(); } catch (NullPointerException e) { System.out.println("null"); }

title: File I/O & Streams
content: Java I/O supports reading/writing using java.io and java.nio. Use BufferedReader/BufferedWriter or Files utility (Java 7+) for simple tasks. Streams API (java.util.stream) helps process collections declaratively.

title: Generics
content: Generics enable type-safe code that works with different types (e.g., List<T>). Use bounded types (T extends Number) to restrict types. Generics avoid casts and ClassCastException at runtime.

title: Multithreading & Concurrency
content: Use Threads or Executors for concurrency. Synchronized, volatile, and concurrent collections (ConcurrentHashMap) help manage shared state. Prefer java.util.concurrent for higher-level primitives (Executors, Locks, Semaphores).
trystarter:
Thread t = new Thread(() -> System.out.println("Hi"));
t.start();

title: Lambda Expressions & Streams
content:
Lambdas provide concise function expressions. Streams API allows map/filter/reduce operations on collections.

Example: list.stream().filter(x->x>0).map(x->x*2).collect(...)

title: JVM, Memory & Tooling
content: Understanding the JVM is key: classloader, heap vs stack, garbage collection. Common tools: javac (compiler), java (runner), javadoc, jmap/jstack for debugging, and build tools like Maven/Gradle.

title: Introduction to JavaScript
content:
JavaScript is a lightweight, interpreted language used to make web pages dynamic. It runs inside browsers and also on servers through Node.js.

Features:
- Dynamically typed
- Event-driven and asynchronous capable
- First-class functions
- Works with web DOM

Usage:
- Frontend (React, Vue, Angular)
- Backend (Node.js)
- Mobile & Desktop apps

title: Variables (var, let, const)
content:
JavaScript variables can be declared using:
- var: old, function-scoped
- let: block-scoped
- const: block-scoped and cannot be reassigned

JS is dynamically typed â€” variable types can change at runtime.

title: Data Types
content:
JavaScript has 8 basic types:
- string
- number
- boolean
- object
- undefined
- null
- symbol
- bigint

Use typeof to check a type.

title: Operators
content:
Common operators:
Arithmetic: + - * / % **
Comparison: == != === !== < <= > >=
Logical: && || !
Assignment: = += -= *= /=

=== compares both value and type. Always prefer === over ==.

title: Strings
content:
Strings can use single (' '), double (" "), or backtick (` ` for template literals) quotes.

Useful methods:
- length
- toUpperCase()
- slice()
- split()
- replace()

Template literals allow embedding variables with ${}.

title: Arrays
content:
Arrays store ordered elements and can grow dynamically.

Useful methods:
- push(), pop()
- shift(), unshift()
- map(), filter(), reduce()
- includes()
- indexOf()
Arrays are zero-indexed.

title: Objects
content:
Objects store key-value pairs.

You can access properties with dot notation or bracket notation.
Objects can store functions, called methods.

title: Conditionals
content:
JavaScript supports if, else if, else blocks.

The ternary operator cond ? val1 : val2 is used for short conditions.
Switch can compare exact values.

title: Loops
content:
Loop types:
- for
- while
- do...while
- for...of (arrays)
- for...in (objects)

Use break to exit loops and continue to skip iterations.

title: Functions
content:
Functions define reusable logic.

Styles:
- Function declaration
- Function expression
- Arrow functions (modern concise syntax)

title: DOM Manipulation
content:
The Document Object Model (DOM) lets JS modify webpage structure.

Common APIs:
- document.getElementById()
- document.querySelector()
- element.innerHTML
- element.style
- addEventListener()

title: Events
content:
Events allow interaction such as clicks, keypress, hover, etc.

Use addEventListener to handle events.
trystarter: // Add a click event to a button

title: Promises & Async/Await
content:
Promises represent future values.

async/await makes asynchronous code look synchronous.

title: Classes (ES6)
content:
JavaScript supports OOP via ES6 classes.

Use constructor() to initialize properties.
Methods are added without function keyword.

title: Modules (import/export)
content:
Modules allow code reuse.

Export values using export, import them using import.
Supported in browser (type='module') and Node.js.
trystarter: // Try writing two modules and import one into another

title: Introduction to TypeScript
content:
TypeScript is JavaScript with types. It adds compile-time safety, modern features, and better tooling. TypeScript code compiles to JavaScript.

Benefits:
- Static typing
- Error checking before runtime
- Strong IDE support
- Great for large applications

title: Types & Type Annotation
content:
TypeScript adds annotations such as:
- string
- number
- boolean
- any
- unknown
- void
- never
- custom types

Helps catch errors early.

title: Arrays & Tuples
content:
Arrays can be typed like string[] or Array<number>.
Tuples define fixed-length arrays with specified types.
codeExample:
let nums: number[] = [1,2,3];
let person: [string, number] = ["Alice", 25];

title: Interfaces
content:
Interfaces define object shapes.
Use them to enforce structure.

title: Functions & Types
content:
Functions have typed parameters and return types.
Optional params: ?
Default params supported.

title: Classes & OOP
content:
TS supports full OOP.
Access modifiers: public, private, protected.
Constructors initialize properties.

title: Generics
content:
Generics make functions and classes reusable with multiple types.
Syntax: <T>

title: Enums & Union Types
content:
Enums define readable constant sets.
Union types allow variables to hold multiple possible types.

title: Modules & Namespaces
content:
Modules organize code across files using import/export.
Namespaces (older feature) group code inside one file.
trystarter: // Create two TS files and import between them

title: Type Narrowing
content:
TS can narrow types based on conditions (typeof, in, instanceof).
Useful for handling union types safely.

title: Decorators
content:
Decorators annotate classes, methods, and properties.
Must enable experimentalDecorators.
Useful in Angular, NestJS.
trystarter: // Try making a simple class decorator

title: Async/Await
content:
Async functions return Promises.
Await pauses execution until a Promise resolves.

title: Type Casting
content:
Use as keyword or <> syntax to cast types.
Useful when dealing with DOM elements or 3rd party libs.
codeExample:
let input = document.getElementById('name') as HTMLInputElement;
console.log(input.value);

title: Mapped & Utility Types
content:
TS includes built-in helpers:
- Partial<T>
- Required<T>
- Readonly<T>
- Record<K,T>

Mapped types let you transform all properties of a type.

title: Advanced Types
content:
Advanced features:
- intersections (&)
- index signatures
- keyof operator
- conditional types (T extends U ? X : Y)
codeExample:
type A={x:number}; type B={y:number};
type C = A & B; // intersection

title: Introduction to C
content:
C is a powerful, low-level programming language used for system programming, operating systems, embedded systems, and performance-critical software.

Key Features:
- Very fast and efficient
- Manual memory management
- Procedural language
- Foundation of C++, Java, Rust, etc.

C programs are compiled using a compiler like GCC.
trystarter:
#include <stdio.h>
int main(){ printf("Your first C program"); }

title: Variables and Data Types
content:
C has several primitive data types:
- int
- float
- double
- char

Variables must be declared before use.
Use sizeof() to check memory size of a type.

title: Operators
content:
C supports:
- Arithmetic: + - * / %
- Comparison: == != < <= > >=
- Logical: && || !
- Assignment: = += -= *=

Integer division drops decimals.

title: Input and Output
content:
Use printf() for output.
Use scanf() for input.
Format specifiers:
- %d for int
- %f for float
- %c for char
- %s for string

title: Control Flow
content:
C supports:
- if / else
- switch
- for
- while
- do...while

Use break to stop loops and continue to skip an iteration.

title: Functions
content:
Functions must be declared before use.
They have return types.
Functions allow code reuse.
codeExample:
int add(int a,int b){return a+b;}
int main(){printf("%d", add(2,3));}

title: Arrays
content:
Arrays store fixed-size, same-type elements.
Index starts from 0.
Pass arrays to functions using pointers.

title: Strings
content:
Strings are char arrays ending with \0.
Use functions from <string.h> like strlen(), strcpy(), strcat().

title: Pointers
content:
Pointers store memory addresses.
Use & to get address, * to dereference.
Pointers are powerful but require caution.

title: Dynamic Memory (malloc, free)
content:
Use malloc() to allocate memory at runtime.
free() releases memory.
Included in <stdlib.h>.

title: Structures
content:
Structures group related variables.
Useful to model objects.
codeExample:
struct Person{char name[20]; int age;};
struct Person p={"Alice",25};

title: File Handling
content:
Use fopen(), fprintf(), fscanf(), fgets(), fclose().
Modes:
- r (read)
- w (write)
- a (append)

title: Preprocessor
content:
Preprocessor runs before compilation.
Common directives:
- #include
- #define
- #ifdef
- #ifndef

title: Header Files
content:
Header files contain declarations.
Use #include to include them.
You can create custom header files.
trystarter: // create a.h with a function declaration

title: Compilation & Memory Layout
content:
C compilation stages:
- Preprocessing
- Compilation
- Assembly
- Linking

Memory layout:
- Text (code)
- Data
- BSS
- Heap
- Stack
trystarter: // try compiling any C file using gcc

title: Introduction to C++
content:
C++ is a high-performance, multi-paradigm language supporting OOP, procedural, and generic programming.
Used in game engines, finance, robotics, and systems programming.

Features:
- Faster than Java/Python
- RAII memory model
- OOP + templates

title: Variables and Types
content:
C++ supports:
- int
- float
- double
- char
- bool
- string (from <string>)
Use auto to infer types.
codeExample:
int x=10; double y=3.5; string s="Hi";
auto z = 100;

title: Operators
content:
C++ supports arithmetic, comparison, logical, bitwise, and assignment operators.
Use static_cast for type conversion.

title: Input & Output
content:
Use cout for output and cin for input.
Include <iostream>.
Use getline() for full string input.

title: Control Flow
content:
C++ supports if, switch, for, while, do-while.
Use break and continue.

title: Functions
content:
Functions must be declared before use.
C++ supports default parameters and function overloading.
codeExample:
int add(int a,int b){return a+b;}
cout<<add(2,3);

title: Arrays & Vectors
content:
Arrays are fixed-size; vectors from <vector> are dynamic.
Vectors are widely used in modern C++.

title: Strings
content:
Use std::string for text.
String operations: length(), substr(), find(), append().

title: Pointers & References
content:
Pointers store memory addresses. References are aliases.
Use & to get address and * to dereference.

title: OOP: Classes & Objects
content:
C++ supports full OOP: classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism.
Use constructors/destructors for resource management.

title: Inheritance & Polymorphism
content:
Derived classes extend base classes.
virtual enables runtime polymorphism.
Use override to mark overridden methods.
codeExample:
class A{public: virtual void show(){cout<<"A";}};
class B:public A{public: void show() override{cout<<"B";}};

title: STL: Vector, Map, Set
content:
The Standard Template Library provides containers and algorithms.
- vector
- set
- map

Use algorithms like sort(), find(), reverse().

title: File I/O
content: Use <fstream>. Supports ifstream, ofstream, fstream.

title: Templates
content:
Templates allow generic programming.
Functions and classes can be written using type parameters.
codeExample:
template<typename T>
T add(T a,T b){return a+b;}
trystarter: template<typename T> T mul(T a,T b){return a*b;}

title: Memory Management
content:
Use new/delete for dynamic memory.
Prefer smart pointers (unique_ptr, shared_ptr) from <memory>.
Avoid memory leaks.

title: Introduction to HTML
content:
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language for creating webpages.
It defines the structure of a webpage using tags.
HTML documents contain elements such as headings, paragraphs, images, and links.

title: HTML Elements
content:
HTML elements are the building blocks of webpages. An element consists of an opening tag, content, and a closing tag:

Content

Elements may contain attributes for extra information.

title: HTML Attributes
content:
Attributes provide additional information about elements.
Attributes are written inside the opening tag.
Examples: href, src, id, class, style.

title: Headings
content:
HTML provides six heading levels: <h1> to <h6>.
<h1> is the largest and <h6> is the smallest.
Headings help structure content and improve SEO.

title: Paragraphs
content:
Paragraphs are defined using

tag. Browsers automatically add space before and after each paragraph.

title: Links
content:
Links are created with the <a> tag.
The href attribute specifies the destination URL.

title: Images
content: Use the tag to display images. Attributes: - src: the image source - alt: alternative text - width, height

title: Lists
content:
HTML supports two main types of lists:
- Ordered list (<ol>)
- Unordered list (<ul>)
List items use <li>.

title: Tables
content:
Tables organize data in rows and columns.
Main tags:
- <table>
- <tr>: table row
- <td>: table data
- <th>: table header

title: Forms
content:
Forms collect user input.
Basic tags:
- <form>
- <input>
- <textarea>
- <button>
Attributes: type, value, placeholder.

title: Semantic Elements
content:
Semantic elements explain their meaning:
Examples:
- <header>
- <footer>
- <section>
- <article>
- <nav>

title: HTML Layout
content:
HTML layout uses semantic tags and division elements.
<div> helps group content.
CSS frameworks help with modern layouts.

title: Audio & Video
content:
HTML supports multimedia content:
- <audio>
- <video>
Attributes: controls, autoplay, loop.

title: Iframes
content:
Iframes embed external pages inside your website.
Often used for videos, maps, embedded tools.

title: HTML Entities
Introduction to CSS
content:
CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) controls the visual appearance of webpages.
It styles HTML elements using selectors and properties.
CSS can be inline, internal, or external.

title: Selectors
content:
Selectors target HTML elements.
Types:
- Element: p
- Class: .box
- ID: #header
- Universal: *

title: Colors
content:
Colors can be specified using:
- names (red)
- hex (#ff0000)
- rgb()
- rgba()
- hsl()

title: Backgrounds
content:
Background properties:
- background-color
- background-image
- background-size
- background-repeat

title: Borders
content:
Border properties:
- border-width
- border-style
- border-color
Use border-radius for rounded corners.

title: Margins
Padding
content:
Padding controls inner spacing.
Padding is inside the border.

title: Box Model
content:
Every element is a box with:
- content
- padding
- border
- margin
Use box-sizing: border-box to include padding & border in width.

title: Text Styling
content:
Common text properties:
- font-size
- font-weight
- text-align
- letter-spacing
- line-height

title: Fonts
content:
Use font-family to set fonts.
Web-safe fonts or Google Fonts can be used.

title: Display Property
content:
Controls how elements behave:
- block
- inline
- inline-block
- none
Use display to create layouts.

title: Flexbox
content:
Flexbox creates 1D layouts.
Properties:
- display: flex
- justify-content
- align-items
- flex-direction

title: Grid
content:
CSS Grid creates 2D layouts.
Properties:
- display: grid
- grid-template-columns
- grid-gap

title: Position
content:
Positions elements using:
- static
- relative
- absolute
- fixed
- sticky

title: Animations
content:
Create animations using @keyframes.
Use animation-name, animation-duration, animation-iteration-count.
codeExample:
@keyframes move { from {left:0;} to {left:100px;} }
div { animation: move 2s infinite; position: relative; }

title: Introduction to PHP
content:
PHP is a server-side scripting language used for dynamic web pages, APIs, and backend systems.
Key Features:
- Interpreted
- Easy integration with HTML
- Works with databases (MySQL, PostgreSQL)
- Powers WordPress, Laravel, and many major platforms

title: Variables & Data Types
content:
Variables in PHP start with a $.
Types:
- String
- Integer
- Float
- Boolean
- Array
- Object
- NULL
PHP is loosely typed.

title: Operators
content:
PHP supports arithmetic (+ - * / %), comparison (== === !=), logical (&& || !), and assignment operators.
=== compares both value and type.

title: Strings
content:
Use single (' ') or double (" ") quotes.
String functions:
- strlen()
- strtoupper()
- strtolower()
- explode()
- implode()

title: Arrays
content:
Types of arrays:
- Indexed arrays
- Associative arrays
- Multidimensional arrays
Use print_r() to inspect arrays.

title: Associative Arrays
content:
Associative arrays store key-value pairs.
Access elements by key.

title: Conditionals
content:
PHP supports if, else if, else, and switch.
Use === for strict comparison.

title: Loops
content:
Loop types:
- for
- while
- do...while
- foreach (best for arrays)

title: Functions
content:
Functions use the function keyword.
Arguments can have default values.
Return values using return.

title: Forms & GET/POST
content:
PHP handles forms using $_GET and $_POST superglobals.
Use method="post" or method="get" in forms.

title: Working with Files
content:
File functions:
- fopen()
- fread()
- fwrite()
- file_get_contents()
- file_put_contents()

title: Sessions
content:
Sessions store user data across pages.
Start sessions using session_start().

title: Cookies
content:
Cookies store data in the user's browser.
Use setcookie() to create cookies.

title: MySQL Database
content:
Use mysqli or PDO to connect to MySQL.
Always escape inputs to prevent SQL injection.

title: Object-Oriented PHP
content:
PHP supports classes, objects, constructors, inheritance.
Use public/private/protected.

title: Introduction to Ruby
content:
Ruby is a dynamic, elegant, purely object-oriented language.
Used heavily in web development via Ruby on Rails.

Features:
- Everything is an object
- Clean, readable syntax
- Dynamic typing

title: Variables & Types
content:
Ruby does not require type declarations.
Variables start with lowercase letters.
Types:
- Integer
- Float
- String
- Boolean
- Array
- Hash

title: Operators
content:
Ruby supports arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.
== checks value, eql? checks type and value.

title: Strings
content:
Ruby strings use quotes.
Interpolation uses #{variable}.
Methods:
- upcase
- downcase
- split
- strip

title: Arrays
content:
Arrays can store multiple types.
Methods: push, pop, map, select, each.

title: Hashes
content:
Hashes store key-value pairs.
Keys can be symbols (:name).
Access using hash[key].

title: Conditionals
content:
Ruby supports if, elsif, else.
You can also use modifier if.

title: Loops
content:
Loop types:
- for
- while
- until
- each
Ruby often prefers each over for.

title: Methods
content:
Define methods with def.
Return is implicit â€” the last expression is returned.
codeExample:
def add(a,b)
  a+b
end
puts add(2,3)

title: Blocks, Procs & Lambdas
content:
Blocks are chunks of code.
Procs and lambdas store blocks.
Syntax: -> for lambdas.

title: Classes & Objects
content:
Ruby is fully OOP.
Classes define objects.
Use initialize for constructors.
trystarter: class Car; def initialize(m); @m=m; end; end

title: Inheritance
content:
Classes use < to inherit.
Child classes inherit methods from parent.
codeExample:
class Animal; def speak; "sound"; end; end
class Dog < Animal; end
puts Dog.new.speak
trystarter: class A; end; class B < A; end

title: Modules
content:
Modules group methods for reuse.
Classes can include modules.
codeExample:
module Greet
  def hello; "Hi"; end
end
class User; include Greet; end

title: File Handling
content:
Use File class to read/write.
Common methods:
- File.open
- File.read
- File.write

title: Ruby on Rails Basics
content:
Rails is a framework built on Ruby.
Follows MVC architecture.
Helps build full-stack web apps quickly.
Commands:
- rails new app
- rails generate model
- rails server
codeExample:
# Rails controller example
class HomeController < ApplicationController
  def index
  end
end
trystarter:
# Try generating a new Rails app
# rails new myapp

title: Introduction to SQL
content:
SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to store, manage, and retrieve data in relational databases.
Popular SQL databases: MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, SQLite.

SQL is used to:
- Insert data
- Update records
- Delete records
- Retrieve (query) data
- Create tables & databases

title: Databases & Tables
INSERT Statement
content:
INSERT adds new records.
Use VALUES to insert row data.
Multiple rows can be inserted at once.

title: SELECT Statement
content:
SELECT retrieves data.
Use * to select all columns.
WHERE filters results.

title: WHERE Clause
content:
Filters results.
Operators: =, >, <, >=, <=, !=
Use LIKE for patterns.
codeExample: SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE 'A%';

title: UPDATE & DELETE
content:
UPDATE modifies existing records.
DELETE removes rows.
Always use WHERE to avoid affecting all records.
codeExample:
UPDATE users SET name='Bob' WHERE id=1;
DELETE FROM users WHERE id=2;
trystarter: UPDATE users SET name='Test' WHERE id=3;

title: ORDER BY
content: Sorts results ascending (ASC) or descending (DESC).
codeExample: SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY name ASC;
trystarter: SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY id DESC;

title: LIMIT
content:
LIMIT restricts the number of returned rows.
Useful for pagination.

title: Aggregate Functions
content:
Aggregate functions:
- COUNT()
- SUM()
- AVG()
- MAX()
- MIN()
Usually used with GROUP BY.

title: GROUP BY
content:
GROUP BY groups rows with the same values.
Use HAVING to filter grouped results.
codeExample: SELECT name, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY name;
trystarter: SELECT id, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY id;

title: Joins (INNER, LEFT, RIGHT)
content:
Joins combine rows from two tables.
INNER JOIN: matching rows only
LEFT JOIN: all left rows + matches
RIGHT JOIN: all right rows + matches
codeExample:
SELECT * FROM orders
INNER JOIN users ON orders.user_id = users.id;
trystarter: SELECT * FROM A INNER JOIN B ON A.id = B.id;

title: Full Outer Join
content:
Returns all rows from both tables whether matched or not.
Not supported in MySQL but can be simulated with UNION.
codeExample:
SELECT * FROM A
FULL OUTER JOIN B ON A.id = B.id;
trystarter: SELECT * FROM A FULL OUTER JOIN B ON A.id=B.id;

title: Constraints
content:
Constraints restrict data:
- PRIMARY KEY
- FOREIGN KEY
- UNIQUE
- NOT NULL
- CHECK

title: Indexes
content:
Indexes improve query performance.
Use on frequently searched columns.
Downside: increases write cost.

title: Views
content:
Views are virtual tables from SELECT statements.
They store no data and help simplify complex queries.
codeExample:
CREATE VIEW v_users AS
SELECT name FROM users;
trystarter: CREATE VIEW v_demo AS SELECT * FROM demo;

title: Introduction to Swift
content:
Swift is Apple's modern, fast programming language for iOS, macOS, watchOS, and tvOS.
It is safe, expressive, and uses type inference.
Designed to replace Objective-C.

title: Variables & Constants
content:
Use var to declare variables and let for constants.
Swift is strongly typed but supports type inference.

title: Data Types
content:
Common types:
- Int
- Double
- Float
- String
- Bool
Use type(of:) to check type.
codeExample:
let x: Int = 10
let y: Double = 3.5

title: Strings
content:
Strings support interpolation using \(variable).
Methods: uppercased(), lowercased(), count.

title: Arrays
content:
Arrays store ordered values.
Mutable: var
Immutable: let

title: Dictionaries
content:
Dictionaries store key-value pairs.
Access safely using optional binding.

title: Conditionals
content:
Swift supports if, else if, else.
Also supports switch with powerful pattern matching.

title: Loops
content:
Loops:
- for
- while
- repeat...while

title: Functions
content:
Functions have labels for parameters.
Return multiple values using tuples.
codeExample:
func add(a:Int, b:Int) -> Int { return a+b }
print(add(a:2,b:3))

title: Optionals
content:
Optionals may hold a value or nil.
Use ? for optional and ! to unwrap.
Prefer safe unwrapping using if let.
codeExample:
var name:String? = "Alice"
if let n=name{ print(n) }

title: Structs
content:
Structs are value types.
They support methods and init().
codeExample:
struct Car{ var model:String }
let c = Car(model:"BMW")
trystarter: struct Point{ var x=0; var y=0 }

title: Classes
content:
Classes are reference types.
Support inheritance.
Initializers required unless using default values.

title: Protocols
content:
Protocols define required methods.
Classes, structs, and enums can adopt protocols.
codeExample:
protocol Greet{ func hi() }
class User:Greet{ func hi(){print("Hi")}}

title: Extensions
content: Extensions add functionality to existing types.
codeExample:
extension String{ func shout()->String{ return uppercased() } }
print("hello".shout())

title: SwiftUI Basics
content:
SwiftUI builds UI declaratively.
Uses Views like Text, Button, VStack.
Updated with state using @State variables.

title: Introduction to Kotlin
content:
Kotlin is a modern, statically-typed language that runs on the JVM and compiles to JavaScript and native binaries. It is concise, safe, and fully interoperable with Java. Widely used for Android development and server-side projects.

Key points:
- Null-safety built into the type system
- Concise syntax with type inference
- Coroutines for async programming
trystarter: fun main() { println("Your first Kotlin program") }

title: Variables & Types
content: Use val for read-only (immutable) variables and var for mutable ones. Kotlin has standard types like Int, Double, String, Boolean. Type inference lets you omit explicit types in many cases.
codeExample:
val name: String = "Alice"
var age = 25 // Int inferred
val pi = 3.14

title: Null Safety
content: Kotlin distinguishes nullable and non-nullable types. Use ? to mark a type nullable (e.g., String?). Use safe-call ?. and Elvis operator ?: to handle nulls gracefully.
codeExample:
var s: String? = null
println(s?.length ?: "No length")

title: Control Flow
content: Kotlin supports if, when (powerful switch replacement), for, while. when can return values and match ranges and types.

title: Functions
content: Declare functions with fun. Support default parameters, named arguments, single-expression functions, and vararg for variable arguments.
codeExample:
fun add(a: Int, b: Int = 0): Int = a + b
println(add(3)) // 3

title: Data Classes
content: data classes automatically provide equals(), hashCode(), toString(), and copy(). Great for modeling immutable data.
codeExample:
data class Person(val name: String, val age: Int)
val p = Person("Alice", 25)
println(p)
trystarter:
data class Point(val x:Int, val y:Int)
println(Point(1,2))

title: Collections (List, Set, Map)
content: Kotlin collections have mutable and immutable variants. Use listOf, mutableListOf, mapOf, mutableMapOf. Many useful extension functions like filter, map, reduce.

title: Lambdas & Higher-Order Functions
content: Functions are first-class. Lambdas use curly braces and implicit it parameter. Higher-order functions accept/return functions.
codeExample:
val sum = { a:Int, b:Int -> a + b }
println(sum(2,3))
val nums = listOf(1,2,3)
println(nums.filter { it % 2 == 1 })

title: Classes & Inheritance
content: Classes are final by default; use open to allow inheritance. Primary constructors are declared in the class header. Use init blocks for initialization logic.

title: Interfaces & Delegation
content: Interfaces can contain default method implementations. Kotlin supports delegation patterns with by keyword for concise composition.
trystarter:
interface A { fun f() }
class B: A { override fun f() {} }

title: Extension Functions
content: You can add functions to existing classes without inheritance using extension functions.

title: Coroutines Basics
content: Coroutines provide lightweight concurrency. Use suspend functions and launch/async in coroutine scopes for non-blocking I/O.
trystarter:
import kotlinx.coroutines.*
runBlocking { println("Hello from coroutine") }

title: Nullability Utilities
content: Useful helpers: let, run, apply, also. Use ?.let { } to operate on nullable values only when non-null.
trystarter:
val n: Int? = null
println(n ?: "No value")

title: Standard Library & I/O
content: Kotlin standard library provides many extensions on Java APIs. Use println, readLine for simple I/O and java.io for files.
codeExample:
println("Enter name:")
val name = readLine()
println("Hello $name")

title: Interoperability with Java
content: Kotlin is fully interoperable with Java â€” you can call Java code from Kotlin and vice versa. Use @JvmStatic, @JvmOverloads, and nullability annotations to ease integration.
trystarter: // Create a Java class and call it from Kotlin project

title: Introduction to Dart
content: Dart is a client-optimized language for fast apps on any platform. Created by Google, used primarily with Flutter for building cross-platform mobile, web, and desktop UIs. It features optional typing, a modern syntax, and a fast VM.
trystarter: void main() { print('Your first Dart program'); }

title: Variables & Types
content: Dart supports var, final, and const. Types include int, double, String, bool, List, Map. Use dynamic to allow any type. final creates single-assignment variable; const is compile-time constant.

title: Null Safety
content: Modern Dart has sound null safety. Types are non-nullable by default; use ? to mark nullable types. Use late for deferred initialization when you are sure a variable will be initialized before use.

title: Control Flow
content: Dart supports if/else, switch, for, while, do-while, and for-in loops. Use collection-if and collection-for inside lists/sets/maps (useful in Flutter UI trees).

title: Functions
content: Functions are first-class. Dart supports named parameters (with {}), optional positional parameters (with []), arrow syntax for single-expression functions, and higher-order functions.

title: Collections: List, Set, Map
content: Common collections: List (ordered), Set (unique), Map (key-value). Support literal syntax and many useful methods like map, where, reduce.

title: Classes & Objects
content: Dart is object-oriented: everything is an object. Constructors, named constructors, and initializer lists are supported. Use this to access instance members.
trystarter:
class Car { String model; Car(this.model); }
print(Car('Tesla').model);

title: Inheritance & Mixins
content: Use extends for single inheritance. Use mixins (mixin keyword or with) to reuse behavior across classes. Use abstract classes to define interfaces with optional implementation.

title: Async: Future, async/await, Streams
content: Dart uses Future for single asynchronous results and Stream for sequences. Use async/await to write asynchronous code in a linear style.
codeExample:
Future<String> load() async { await Future.delayed(Duration(seconds:1)); return 'data'; }
void main() async { print(await load()); }

title: Null-aware Operators
content: Null-aware operators simplify null handling: ?? (if-null), ?., ??=, and ! (assert non-null).

title: Functional Style & Lambdas
content: Dart supports closures and concise arrow functions. Use higher-order functions and collection transformations for expressive code.

title: Generics
content: Generics add type safety to collections and classes: List<T>, Map<K,V>, and generic classes/functions.
codeExample:
class Box<T> { T value; Box(this.value); }
print(Box<int>(5).value);

title: Exception Handling
content: Use try/catch/finally for exceptions. Optionally catch specific exception types and rethrow when needed.

title: Interoperability & Packages (pub)
content: Use pub.dev to find packages and add them to pubspec.yaml. Flutter uses the same ecosystem. Use import to include packages.
codeExample:
import 'package:http/http.dart' as http;
// then use http.get(...)
trystarter: // add dependency in pubspec.yaml and run pub get

title: Flutter Basics (Intro)
content: Flutter is a UI toolkit built on Dart. Widgets compose the UI in a tree. StatelessWidget and StatefulWidget are foundational building blocks. Use hot reload for fast iteration.
codeExample:
import 'package:flutter/material.dart';
void main() => runApp(MaterialApp(home: Scaffold(body: Center(child: Text('Hello')))));
trystarter: // Create a simple StatelessWidget with Text('Hi')

title: Introduction to C#
content:
C# (C-Sharp) is a modern, object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft. It runs on the .NET platform and is used for building desktop apps, web apps, games (Unity), APIs, and cloud services.

Key Features:
- Strongly typed
- Automatic memory management (Garbage Collector)
- Supports OOP, LINQ, async/await

title: Variables & Data Types
content:
Common C# types include:
int, float, double, string, bool, char.
var enables type inference.
Constants use the const keyword.

title: Operators
content: C# supports arithmetic (+ - * / %), assignment (= += -=), comparison (== != > <), logical (&& || !), and ternary (condition ? a : b).

title: Strings
content: Strings are immutable in C#. Use interpolation with $" ". Common methods: Length, ToUpper(), ToLower(), Contains(), Replace().

title: Arrays & Lists
content:
Arrays have a fixed size. Lists (List<T>) are dynamic.
Use indexing to access items.
codeExample:
int[] nums = {1,2,3};
var list = new List<int>{1,2,3};

title: Control Flow
content:
Use if, else if, else for conditions.
switch provides pattern matching.
Loop types: for, while, do-while, foreach.

title: Methods
content: Methods can have parameters, return types, and optional/default values. Methods can be static or instance methods.
codeExample:
static int Add(int a,int b){ return a+b; }
Console.WriteLine(Add(2,3));

title: Classes & Objects
content:
Classes define data and behavior. Objects are instances of classes.
Fields store data, methods perform actions.
Constructors initialize objects.
trystarter: class Car{ public string Model; public Car(string m){Model=m;} }

title: Inheritance
content: C# supports single inheritance using :. Base classes can be extended. Use base() to call parent constructors.

title: Polymorphism
content:
Use virtual and override for runtime polymorphism.
Allows methods to behave differently in derived classes.
codeExample:
class A{ public virtual void Show(){ Console.WriteLine("A"); }}
class B: A{ public override void Show(){ Console.WriteLine("B"); }}
trystarter: class X{ public virtual void F(){} }

title: Interfaces
content: Interfaces specify methods without implementation. Classes must implement all members.
codeExample:
interface IRun{ void Run(); }
class A: IRun{ public void Run(){ Console.WriteLine("Running"); }}

title: Exception Handling
content:
Use try, catch, finally to handle exceptions.
Common exceptions: NullReferenceException, IndexOutOfRangeException.
codeExample:
try{ int x=int.Parse("a"); }
catch(Exception e){ Console.WriteLine(e.Message); }

title: LINQ Basics
content:
Language Integrated Query (LINQ) allows querying collections using SQL-like syntax.
Supports filtering, projection, ordering.

title: Async & Await
content:
async and await simplify asynchronous programming.
Tasks represent background work. await pauses until the task completes.
codeExample: async Task Hello(){ await Task.Delay(1000); Console.WriteLine("Done"); }

title: File Handling
content:
Use File and FileStream for reading and writing files.
Common methods: File.ReadAllText(), File.WriteAllText().

title: Introduction to Go
content:
Go (Golang) is a fast, statically typed language created by Google. It is designed for simplicity, concurrency, and performance.

Key features:
- Very fast compilation
- Built-in concurrency with goroutines
- Simple syntax like C but memory-safe
- Great for backend, cloud, and system programming

title: Variables & Types
content:
Use var to declare variables. := infers type. Go types include int, float64, string, bool.
Constants declared with const.
codeExample:
var age int = 25
name := "Alice"
const pi = 3.14

title: Functions
content: Functions use the func keyword. Go supports multiple return values and named return values.
codeExample:
func add(a int, b int) int { return a+b }
fmt.Println(add(2,3))

title: Control Flow
content: Flow control includes if/else, switch, for loops. Go does not have while; for can do everything.
codeExample:
for i:=1;i<=5;i++{ fmt.Println(i) }
if x:=10; x>5 { fmt.Println("ok") }

title: Arrays & Slices
content: Arrays have fixed length. Slices are dynamic and are the most used collection type. Use append() to grow slices.

title: Maps
content: Maps are key-value containers like dictionaries. Keys must be comparable types.

title: Structs
content: Structs are custom types grouping fields. Instances created with literal syntax or using new().
codeExample:
type Person struct{ Name string; Age int }
p := Person{"Alice",25}

title: Methods
content: Methods are functions with receiver types. You can attach methods to structs. Receiver can be value or pointer.

title: Pointers
content: Go supports pointers but not pointer arithmetic. Use & to get address and * to dereference.

title: Interfaces
content: Interfaces define behavior. Types implement interfaces implicitly by matching method signatures.

title: Error Handling
content: Errors in Go are values. Functions often return (result, error). Use errors.New() or fmt.Errorf() to create errors.
codeExample: func div(a,b int)(int,error){ if b==0{return 0,fmt.Errorf("zero div")} return a/b,nil }

title: Goroutines
content: Goroutines are lightweight threads used with the go keyword. Great for concurrency.

title: Channels
content: Channels allow communication between goroutines. Use <- to send and receive values.
codeExample:
ch := make(chan int)
go func(){ ch<-5 }()
fmt.Println(<-ch)

title: File Handling
content: Use os and ioutil packages to read/write files. Handle errors properly.

title: Modules & Packages
content: Go uses modules (go.mod). Use go mod init to start a module and go get to fetch dependencies.

title: Introduction to Rust
content:
Rust is a systems programming language focused on safety, performance, and concurrency.
Key Features:
- Memory safety without garbage collector
- Ownership & Borrowing system
- Zero-cost abstractions
- High-performance
Used for OS development, game engines, CLI tools, and web backends.

title: Variables & Mutability
content:
Variables are immutable by default. Use mut to make them mutable.
Rust is statically typed but supports type inference.

title: Data Types
content:
Common types:
- Integers: i32, u32, i64
- Floats: f32, f64
- Bool
- Char
- String & str
Rust is strongly typed and supports explicit typing.
codeExample:
let a: i32 = 10;
let b: f64 = 2.5;

title: Ownership
content:
Rust's core feature is ownership:
1. Each value has a variable as its owner.
2. Only one owner at a time.
3. Value is dropped when owner goes out of scope.
Prevents memory errors and double frees.
codeExample:
let s = String::from("hello");
let t = s; // ownership moves// println!("{}", s); // error

title: Borrowing & References
content:
Borrowing allows using data without taking ownership.
& creates references.
Mutable and immutable borrow rules prevent data races.

title: Slices
content:
Slices reference a portion of a collection.
Commonly used for strings and arrays.
codeExample:
let s = String::from("hello world");
let part = &s[0..5];

title: Functions
content:
Functions use fn keyword.
Return values use -> type.
Last expression without semicolon becomes the return value.
codeExample:
fn add(a: i32, b: i32) -> i32 { a + b }
println!("{}", add(2,3));

title: Control Flow
content:
Rust supports if/else, loop, while, for.
if is an expression and can return values.

title: Structs
content: Structs group related data. Instantiate with field names. Use impl blocks for methods.
codeExample:
struct Person { name: String, age: u32 }
let p = Person { name:"Alice".into(), age:25 };

title: Enums
content: Enums define multiple possible variants. Useful with match expressions.
codeExample:
enum Color { Red, Green, Blue }
let c = Color::Red;

title: Pattern Matching
content:
match compares a value against patterns.
Very powerful alternative to switch.

title: Traits
content: Traits define shared behavior like interfaces. Types implement traits using impl.

title: Error Handling
content:
Rust uses Result<T,E> for recoverable errors.
? operator propagates errors.

title: Vectors
content:
Vectors are growable arrays.
Use vec![] macro.
Push items using push().

title: Concurrency with Threads
content:
Rust uses std::thread::spawn for multithreading.
Ownership guarantees prevent data races.

title: Introduction to R
content:
R is a language designed for statistical computing, data analysis, and visualization.
Widely used by data scientists, statisticians, and researchers.
Features:
- Vectorized operations
- Built-in statistical functions
- Strong community
- ggplot2 for visualization

title: Variables & Data Types
content:
R has six basic data types:
- numeric
- integer
- character
- logical
- complex
- raw
Variables use <- or =.

title: Vectors
content:
Vectors are fundamental data structures in R.
Use c() to create vectors.
Operations automatically apply element-wise.

title: Matrices
content:
Matrices are 2D homogeneous structures.
Use matrix() function.
Access elements using [row, col].

title: Data Frames
content:
Data frames store tabular data.
Columns can be different types.
Use data.frame() to create.

title: Lists
content:
Lists can store mixed data types.
Useful for modeling structured data.

title: Factors
content:
Factors represent categorical data.
Useful in statistics and charts.
Use factor() to convert vectors.

title: Reading & Writing Files
content:
R supports CSV, TXT, Excel, and more.
Common functions: read.csv(), write.csv().

title: Basic Plotting
content:
Use plot() for quick visualizations.
Supports scatter, line, histogram, etc.

title: Functions
content:
Define functions with function().
Functions can return any object.

title: Apply Family (apply, lapply, sapply)
content:
Apply functions iterate over data efficiently.
apply: matrices
tlapply: lists
sapply: simplified list output

title: dplyr Basics
content:
dplyr is a powerful data manipulation library.
Key verbs:
- select()
- filter()
- mutate()
- summarize()
- group_by()

title: ggplot2 Basics
content:
ggplot2 builds layered graphics.
The grammar of graphics allows flexible visualizations.

title: Statistical Functions
content:
R includes many built-in statistical tools:
mean(), median(), sd(), var(), cor().

title: Machine Learning in R
content:
Packages like caret, randomForest, e1071 support ML.
Steps:
- Load data
- Split dataset
- Train model
- Evaluate accuracy

title: Introduction to Julia
content:
Julia is a high-performance programming language designed for numerical computing, data science, and machine learning.
Key Features:
- Fast like C, easy like Python
- Multiple dispatch
- Built-in package manager
- Excellent for scientific computing (linear algebra, AI)

title: Variables & Types
content:
Variables are dynamically typed.
Types include Int64, Float64, String, Bool, Array, Tuple.
Use typeof() to check type.

title: Arrays
content:
Arrays are flexible, fast, and can be multidimensional.
Use [] to create arrays.
Supports slicing and broadcasting.

title: Tuples
content:
Tuples are immutable, fixed-size collections.
Useful for returning multiple values.

title: Dictionaries
content:
Dictionaries store key-value pairs.
Access using [] syntax.

title: Control Flow
content:
Julia supports if/elseif/else, while, for loops.
for loops are fast due to optimized compiler.

title: Functions
content:
Functions are declared using function keyword or inline syntax.
Julia supports multiple dispatch.

title: Multiple Dispatch
content:
Juliaâ€™s most unique feature.
Function behavior changes depending on argument types.

title: Modules
content:
Modules organize code and prevent name conflicts.
Use module/end and import/export.
codeExample:
module MyMod
  export hello
  hello() = println("hi")
end

title: File Handling
content:
Read/write using open(), read(), write().
Use do block for safe closing.

title: Plotting (Plots.jl)
content:
Julia supports plotting using Plots.jl, Makie, Gadfly.
Plots.jl is the most popular.

title: DataFrames.jl
content:
DataFrames.jl is Julia's equivalent of pandas in Python.
Stores tabular data.

title: Linear Algebra
content:
Julia has built-in linear algebra optimized with BLAS.
Supports matrices, eigenvalues, factorizations.

title: Performance Tips
content:
To optimize code:
- Use type annotations
- Avoid global variables
- Use vectorized operations
- Avoid unnecessary allocations

title: Machine Learning in Julia
content:
Julia has modern ML libraries:
- Flux.jl (deep learning)
- MLJ.jl (traditional ML)
- Knet.jl
Easy to deploy models with high performance.

title: Introduction to Scala
content:
Scala is a powerful hybrid programming language that blends object-oriented and functional programming.
Runs on JVM and interoperates with Java.
Used for big data (Apache Spark), backend systems, and distributed computing.

title: Variables & Types
content:
Use val for immutable values and var for mutable.
Scala has strong static typing with inference.
Common types: Int, Double, String, Boolean, List, Map.

title: Strings
content:
Strings support interpolation using s"...$var".
Useful methods: toUpperCase, length, replace.

title: Lists
content:
Lists are immutable sequences.
Use :: to prepend.
Use map, filter, reduce for functional operations.

title: Maps
content:
Maps store key-value pairs.
Immutable by default. Use -> syntax to create entries.

title: Tuples
content:
Tuples hold fixed-size groups of elements.
Access with _1, _2, etc.

title: Control Flow
content: Scala supports if/else, match (powerful pattern matching), for comprehensions, and while loops.

title: Functions
content:
Functions are first-class.
Syntax: def name(args): ReturnType.
Supports anonymous functions and higher-order functions.

title: Classes & Objects
content:
Scala classes can have constructor parameters.
Objects are singletons.
Companion objects allow shared logic.
codeExample:
class Person(val name:String)
val p = new Person("Alice")

title: Inheritance
content:
Use extends to derive classes.
override keyword required for overriding methods.
codeExample:
class Animal{ def speak()=println("sound") }
class Dog extends Animal{ override def speak()=println("woof") }
trystarter: class A{}; class B extends A{}

title: Traits
content:
Traits are like interfaces but can contain implementations.
Classes mix in traits using extends or with.

title: Case Classes
content: Case classes provide immutability, equals(), toString(), and pattern matching for free.

title: Pattern Matching
content:
match is a powerful tool for destructuring and control flow.
Supports pattern guards and type matching.

title: Collections & Functional Operations
content:
Scala collections are rich:
- map
- filter
- reduce
- fold
Immutable collections encouraged for safety.

title: Scala & Big Data (Spark)
content:
Scala is the primary language for Apache Spark.
Spark provides distributed computing for large datasets.
RDDs, DataFrames, and Datasets are core concepts.
